# {.tabset .tabset-fade .tabset-pills}

### Abstract

Utah Division of Wildlife Resources (UDWR, Moab, UT) expended 74.9 hours of electrofishing effort under Project 123d to remove nonnative walleye and smallmouth bass from the upper Colorado River Basin in 2021. Crews focused removal efforts within specific subreaches where catch rates are highest: downstream of Tusher Diversion (River Mile (RM) 128.0 - 107.0) on the Green River and below Westwater Canyon (RM 116.8 -  68.0) on the Colorado River. A total of 139 walleye and 1201 smallmouth bass were encountered throughout sampling in 2021. While walleye encounters were similar to recent years, smallmouth bass captures on the Lower Colorado River were substantially more frequent. <br><br>

document.querySelector('.lnlt').textContent;\n      console.log(txt);\n      //txt.innerText.focus();\n      //txt.select();\n      setClipboardText('\"' + txt + '\"');\n      }\n      });\n\n      }\n      ).call(this.getMap(), el, x, data);\n}","data":null},{"code":"function(el, x, data) {\n  return (function(el,x,data){\n           var map = this;\n\n           map.on('keypress', function(e) {\n               console.log(e.originalEvent.code);\n               var key = e.originalEvent.code;\n               if (key === 'KeyE') {\n                   var bb = this.getBounds();\n                   var txt = JSON.stringify(bb);\n                   console.log(txt);\n\n                   setClipboardText('\\'' + txt + '\\'');\n               }\n           })\n        }).call(this.getMap(), ```
</center>

Figure 1. Removal reaches sampled during 2021: Tusher Reach (RM 128.0 - 107.0) and Lower Colorado Reach (RM 116.8 - 68.0).

<br><br>


___


## Green River

<br><br>

<center>
![A photograph showing UDWR fisheries technician Carlos Montanez with 14 walleye dislpayed on the deck of an electrofishing boat. All fish are oriented heads left and tails right and have white zipties secruing identification tags throughh their gills. A scale, bucket and measuring board are also visible.](C:/Users/cmichaud/OneDrive - DOI/Documents/Projects/udwr-mfo_data-mgt/Reports/Assets/walleye-carlos.jpg)
</center>  

UDWR fisheries technician Carlos Montanez with 14 walleye on the deck of an electrofishing boat. All fish were later frozen and transported to Fort Collins, CO for use in an energetics study. 

___

<br><br>

### Tusher Reach

The Green River peaked at 9,450 cfs on 28 May 2021, measured on USGS gage 09315000, located at the town of Green River, Utah (Figure 2). Crews began sampling below Tusher Diversion on 23 March 2021 and ended on 02 June 2021. Main channel temperatures ranged between 9.8 - 21.3 Â°C during sampling (Table 1). Crews sampled between river miles 128.0 and 107.0 (Figure 1).

<br><br>




<center>
![This chart has title 'Figure 2. Discharge on the Green River, 2021'. It has the subtitle 'Sampling events noted with blue points'. It has x-axis '' with labels Jan, Apr and Jul. It has y-axis 'Discharge (cfs)' with labels 2500, 5000 and 7500. It has 2 layers. Layer 1 is a set of 1 line. Line 1 connects 245 points. Layer 1 has size set to 1. Layer 2 is a set of 11 points. Layer 2 has shape set to fillable circle. Layer 2 has size set to 4. Layer 2 has fill set to brilliant blue. Layer 2 has alpha set to 0.8. This figure is depicts the dates on which sampling occurred (points) and the river discharge (line) during the sampling period. The sampling dates and river discharge follow - March 23: 2010 cfs, March 30: 2050 cfs, April 05: 1830 cfs, April 13: 2470 cfs, April 19: 2360 cfs, May 11: 3350 cfs, May 18: 3190 cfs, May 19: 3020 cfs, May 20: 3150 cfs, May 27: 8810 cfs, June 02: 6580 cfs](123d_annual-rept_files/figure-html/gr-dis-fig-1.png)

</center>


A total of 31.4 hours of effort were allocated to this reach and  101 walleye were removed (catch-per-unit-effort [cpue] = 3.22 fish-per-hour).  Walleye catch rates are similar to recent years (Table 4), but with increased effort substantially more walleye have been removed in 2019, 2020 and 2021 than previous years. Walleye total lengths within this reach were also similar to recent years (mean = 460 mm, range = 345 - 613 mm) (Figure 3). Additionally, researchers removed 37 smallmouth bass (cpue = 1.18 fish-per-hour) and 2 northern pike (cpue = 0.06 fish-per-hour) (Table 2). Native fish encounters are summarized in Table 3. 
  
<br><br>

## Colorado River

<br><br>

<center>
![A photograph showing a researcher on the front of an electrofishing boat, holding a dip net. They are wearing black pants and a blue shirt with their back to the camera. The river infront of the boat is tan in color. The black shist and sandstone canyons of Westwater are visible in the background.](C:/Users/cmichaud/OneDrive - DOI/Documents/Projects/udwr-mfo_data-mgt/Reports/Assets/efboat-westwater1.jpg)
</center>

Electrofishing below Westwater Canyon.

___

<br><br>

### Lower Colorado Reach

The Colorado River, at USGS gage 09180500, located near Cisco, UT, peaked at 8,300 cfs on 07 June 2021 (Figure 4).  Crews began sampling the lower Colorado reach on 29 April 2021 and ended on 12 August 2021. Main channel temperatures ranged between 14.4 - 25.1Â°C during sampling (Table 1). Crews sampled between river miles 116.8 and 68.0 (Figure 1).  UDWR began non-native fish removal efforts within this reach in 2014, over the past six years researchers have documented an increasing trend in smallmouth bass encounters (Table 7). During the 2020 and 2021 field seasons, UDWR has applied additional effort, compared to past years, to combat the increasing smallmouth bass numbers.


<br><br>




<center>
![This chart has title 'Figure 4. Discharge on the Colorado River, 2021'. It has the subtitle 'Sampling events noted with blue points'. It has x-axis '' with labels Jan, Apr and Jul. It has y-axis 'Discharge (cfs)' with labels 2000, 4000, 6000 and 8000. It has 2 layers. Layer 1 is a set of 1 line. The line is broken or missing where NA values appear or where points exceed the plot boundaries. Line 1 connects 245 points. Layer 1 has size set to 1. Layer 2 is a set of 13 points. Layer 2 has shape set to fillable circle. Layer 2 has size set to 4. Layer 2 has fill set to brilliant blue. Layer 2 has alpha set to 0.8. This figure is depicts the dates on which sampling occurred (points) and the river discharge (line) during the sampling period.](123d_annual-rept_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png)

</center>

A total of 43.5 hours of effort was allocated to this reach and crews removed 38 walleye (catch-per-unit-effort [cpue] = 0.87 fish-per-hour).  Additionally, 1164 smallmouth bass were removed (cpue = 26.78) within this reach (Table 5, Figure 5). This catch-rate is substantially higher than recent years (Table 7). This is particularly concerning due to the close proximity of the Westwater Canyon humpback chub population. Smallmouth bass mean total length in 2021 was 192 mm (range = 50 - 392 mm) (Figure 6). Ancillary captures of native species are noted in Table 6. 


<br><br>

## Bureau of Reclamation Information

### COLORADO RIVER RECOVERY PROGRAM			RECOVERY PROGRAM
### FY 2021 ANNUAL PROJECT REPORT				PROJECT NUMBER: <u> 123d </u>

I.	Project Title: Walleye control in the Lower Green and Colorado Rivers.

II.	Bureau of Reclamation Agreement Number(s): <br><br> 
  UDWR Moab: R19AP00059 <br>                                                 
  Project/Grant Period:  
  Start date (Mo/Day/Yr): 10/01/2019  
  End date: (Mo/Day/Yr): 09/30/2024  
  Reporting period end date: 09/30/2020  
  Is this the final report? Yes __ No  <u> X </u> <br><br>
  
  
III.	Principal Investigator(s): <br><br>
  Chris Michaud  
  Utah Division of Wildlife Resources  
  1165 S Hwy 191, Suite 4, 
  Moab, UT 84532  
  Phone: 435-259-3784;  
  E-mail: cmichaud@utah.gov <br><br>


IV.	Abstract: <br><br>
Utah Division of Wildlife Resources (UDWR, Moab, UT) expended 74.9 hours of electrofishing effort under Project 123d to remove nonnative walleye from the upper Colorado River Basin in 2021. Crews focused removal efforts within specific subreaches where walleye catch rates are highest: downstream of Tusher Diversion (River Mile (RM) 128.0 - 107.0) on the Green River and below Westwater Canyon (RM 116.8 -  68.0) on the Colorado River. A total of 139 walleye and 1201 smallmouth bass were encountered throughout sampling in 2021. While walleye encounters were similar to recent years, smallmouth bass captures on the Lower Colorado River were substantially more frequent. <br><br>


V.	Study Schedule: <br><br>
2014-ongoing <br><br>

VI.	Relationship to RIPRAP: <br>  
GENERAL RECOVERY PROGRAM SUPPORT ACTION PLAN   
Reduce negative impacts of nonnative fishes and sportfish management 
activities (nonnative and sportfish management).  
Reduce negative interactions between nonnative and endangered fishes.  
Identify and implement viable active control measures. <br>  
GREEN RIVER ACTION PLAN: MAINSTEM  
Reduce impacts of nonnative fishes and sportfish management activities 
(nonnative and sportfish management).  
Reduce negative impacts to endangered fishes from sportfish management
activities.  
Develop and implement control programs for nonnative fishes in river reaches
occupied by the endangered fishes to identify required levels of control. Each
control activity will be evaluated for effectiveness, and then continued as needed. <br>  
COLORADO RIVER ACTION PLAN: MAINSTEM  
Reduce impacts of nonnative fishes and sportfish management activities
(nonnative and sportfish management).  
Reduce negative interactions between nonnative and endangered fishes.  
Develop basinwide aquatic management plan to reduce nonnative fish impacts
while providing sportfishing opportunities. <br><br>

VII.	Accomplishment of FY 2021 Tasks and Deliverables, Discussion of Initial Findings and Shortcomings: <br><br>
See reach specific analysis tabs <br><br>

VIII.	Additional noteworthy observations: <br><br>
See reach specific analysis tabs <br><br>

IX.	Recommendations: <br><br>  

    * **Tusher Reach (Green River)**  
  Continued application of effort between Tusher Diversion and Green River
  State Park (RM 128-120) as this segment has the highest catch rates for walleye in
  the reach. Removal should be conducted spring through early summer, or when justified by 
  noteworthy catch rates. <br><br> 

    * **Below Westwater Canyon (Colorado River)**  
  Continued application of effort between Big Hole camp and Fish Ford (RM 116-105.5). Removal should be 
  conducted spring through early summer, or when justified by noteworthy catch rates of walleye *or* 
  smallmouth bass. <br><br>

X.	Project Status: <br><br>
On track and ongoing <br><br>
